demographics.name: John Doe
demographics.supportServices: Inpatient admission to oncology floor, physical and occupational therapy consults placed for neurologic rehabilitation.
demographics.mobility: Impaired; requires assistance for all transfers due to severe lower extremity weakness (3/5 strength). Unable to ambulate. ECOG Performance Status 3.

diagnosis.primary: Malignant Spinal Cord Compression at T10-T11
diagnosis.pathologicStage: Metastatic Disease, primary likely lung cancer (pending full staging and biopsy).
diagnosis.symptomsAtPresentation: Patient presented to the ED with a 3-day history of rapidly progressive lower extremity weakness, inability to walk, severe mid-back pain (9/10), and new onset of urinary retention.
pathologyFindings: No new biopsy of the spinal lesion was performed due to the emergent need for treatment. Diagnosis is based on imaging findings in the context of a likely new cancer diagnosis.
diagnosis.relevantHistory: Patient has a 50 pack-year smoking history but no prior cancer diagnosis. He has been experiencing a chronic cough and unintentional weight loss over the past 3 months.
diagnosis.baselineStatus: Acutely ill with severe neurologic compromise. ECOG 3 (severely limited, confined to bed/chair). Foley catheter placed for urinary retention.

treatmentPlan.neurosurgery: Dr. Alice Crane (Consulted, no surgical intervention recommended)
treatmentPlan.targetVolumeSummary: The PTV encompasses the T10 and T11 vertebral bodies where the compression is occurring, plus one vertebral body above (T9) and one below (T12) to cover potential microscopic epidural extension.
treatmentPlan.techniqueSummary: A simple 3D-Conformal AP/PA (Anterior-Posterior/Posterior-Anterior) technique is used for rapid planning and immediate treatment initiation to decompress the spinal cord.
treatmentPlan.concurrentChemo: None (Focus is on emergent RT and steroids).
medications: Dexamethasone 10 mg IV bolus given in ED, followed by a standing dose of 4 mg PO every 6 hours.
Docusate sodium for bowel regimen due to opioids and immobility.
therapistAlerts: This is an oncologic emergency. Patient has significant neurologic deficits.
Use extreme caution during transfers. Log-roll precautions must be maintained at all times to protect the spinal cord.
Assess motor and sensory function in lower extremities *before and after* each treatment and document any change.
Report any worsening of neurologic symptoms (increased weakness, sensory loss, loss of bowel/bladder control) to the physician immediately.
Patient is on high-dose steroids; be aware of potential side effects.

ctSimulation.setupInstructions: Supine in a custom Vac-Lok bag as tolerated due to severe back pain. Arms at side. SAD setup.
ctSimulation.referenceMarks: 3-point tattoos at isocenter projections (AP and bilateral laterals).
ctSimulation.ctNotes: Emergent CT simulation performed for rapid 3D-CRT planning. The simulation was fused with the diagnostic MRI to accurately define the target volume and the location of the spinal cord.

dosimetry.constraints: Spinal Cord Max dose < 28 Gy (achieved 24.5 Gy).
dosimetry.planNotes: Emergent palliative RT plan for Malignant Spinal Cord Compression. Plan provides dose to the compressive tumor while respecting the tolerance of the spinal cord.

igrtProtocol.type: kV Imaging (Orthogonal Pair) or MV Portal Imaging
igrtProtocol.alignment: Match to the bony anatomy of the thoracic spine (T9-T12).

fractions.organTargetChecks: kV images matched to T9-T12 spine. Spinal cord block fully covers cord.
fractions.instructionsGiven: Reassured that treatment goal is to prevent paralysis and relieve pain.
fractions.dailyNotes: First fraction delivered emergently on the evening of simulation. Patient transferred to table via slider board with 4-person lift, maintaining log-roll precautions.

fractions.siteSpecificSideEffects: Back pain improving (5/10). Reports slight return of sensation in feet.
fractions.instructionsGiven: Continue steroids as ordered. PT to evaluate at bedside today.
fractions.dailyNotes: OTV today. Patient reports subjective improvement in pain and some sensory function. Objective motor strength remains 3/5. Encouraging early response.

fractions.siteSpecificSideEffects: Back pain significantly improved (2/10). LE strength improved to 4/5. Able to ambulate short distances with walker and PT.
fractions.instructionsGiven: End-of-treatment instructions provided. Will continue steroid taper. Must continue with intensive PT/OT.
fractions.dailyNotes: Final fraction completed. Patient has had an excellent clinical response with significant neurologic recovery. Transferred to inpatient rehab unit following treatment.

imagingAndReports.summary: Malignant Spinal Cord Compression at T10-T11 from an epidural tumor.

reportDetails.protocol: MRI Thoracic Spine with and without Gadolinium
reportDetails.findings: There is a pathologic fracture of the T10 vertebral body with an associated soft tissue mass that extends posteriorly into the epidural space. This results in severe stenosis of the spinal canal and direct compression and displacement of the thoracic spinal cord at the T10-T11 level. The cord itself shows signs of edema.
reportDetails.impression: Malignant Spinal Cord Compression at T10-T11. This is a neurologic emergency.

labResults.notes: Mild leukocytosis, may be reactive or related to stress/steroids.

progressNotes.author: ED Physician
progressNotes.summary: Patient presented to ED with progressive bilateral lower extremity weakness and back pain, now unable to walk. Exam reveals 3/5 strength in lower extremities and decreased sensation below the umbilicus. Urgent MRI of the T-spine was ordered, which confirmed Malignant Spinal Cord Compression. Patient was immediately started on high-dose IV Dexamethasone. Neurosurgery and Radiation Oncology were consulted emergently.

progressNotes.author: Dr. Alice Crane (Neurosurgery)
progressNotes.summary: Reviewed case and imaging. Patient has MSCC at T10-11 from a presumed metastatic lung cancer. Given the location and circumferential nature of the compression, he is not a good candidate for emergent surgical decompression. Emergent radiation therapy is the recommended course of action to prevent permanent neurologic deficit.

progressNotes.author: Dr. Robert Green
progressNotes.summary: Saw patient emergently for MSCC. Neurologic deficits are significant. After discussion with neurosurgery, patient will proceed with emergent palliative radiation. A rapid 3D plan to 30 Gy in 10 fractions was created. The first fraction was delivered this evening. The primary goal is to preserve and hopefully improve neurologic function.
